## Accessing and Assigning Vector Elements

We can access or modify specific elements in a vector using square brackets `[]`. To retrieve the value at a specific position, we use the element’s index inside the brackets. Similarly, we can assign new values to individual elements by specifying their index.


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
(y <- 1:5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3 4 5
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
y[3]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
y[1] <- 77
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 77  2  3  4  5
```


:::
:::



To modify multiple elements at once, we provide a vector of indices inside the brackets. 


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
y[c(2, 4)] <- -22
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1]  77 -22   3 -22   5
```


:::
:::



::: {.callout-note}

Note that when subsetting, all indices must be placed inside a single pair of square brackets. Using a comma inside `[]` is reserved for multi-dimensional structures like matrices or data frames—and will result in an error when used with vectors.

:::
